title: MEX: Memory-efficient Approach to Referring Multi-Object Tracking
author: Huu-Thien Tran (University of Science Vietnam National University, Ho Chi Minh City), Thai-Son Tran (University of Science Vietnam National University, Ho Chi Minh City), Phuoc-Sang Pham (University of Science Vietnam National University, Ho Chi Minh City), Khoa Luu (Department of Computer Science and Computer Engineering University of Arkansas), ...
relevance_why: The approach's efficiency in multi-object tracking may inspire new methods for audio/object tracking tasks, particularly when integrating with textual descriptions.
background: Referring multi-object tracking aims to identify and track specific objects within video frames based on natural language descriptions, enhancing tracking flexibility and accuracy.
contribution: This paper introduces the Memory-Efficient Cross-Modality (MEX) module to solve the referring multi-object tracking task, achieving improved memory usage and inference speed, surpassing the performance of baseline methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods such as iKUN require end-to-end training and have high memory usage, making them less suitable for resource-constrained environments.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by decoupling the referring and tracking tasks, allowing for a memory-efficient architecture that supports off-the-shelf trackers without retraining.

key_innovation: The MEX module efficiently integrates visual and textual data using a unique attention mechanism tailored for three data sources, enhancing multi-object tracking.
real_world_impact: The method's memory efficiency and reduced processing time can lead to broader applications in autonomous driving and surveillance systems, where resource constraints are critical.
limitations: The tracker struggles with accurately identifying composite objects and filtering based on motion queries.

new_terms.referring multi-object tracking: **Referring multi-object tracking** is a task that combines object tracking with natural language descriptions, allowing the system to focus on specific objects as described verbally.
new_terms.Memory-Efficient Cross-Modality (MEX): **MEX** is a proposed module that optimizes the processing of visual and textual information concurrently in a more resource-efficient manner.
